title: How to Upgrade Kitchen Cabinets

steps.headline: Choose a light-colored paint to make your kitchen look bigger.
steps.description: To create a more open, spacious feel, look for paints in paler shades. Avoid glossy paints, as these will show any painting imperfections more visibly. Acrylic, or water-based, paints typically create fewer fumes and are easier to clean up than oil-based paints. Make your upper cabinets a lighter color and the bottom cabinets darker to make your space look more trendy. Make sure the 2 colors are complementary to one another.

steps.headline: Take your cabinet doors off their hinges.
steps.description: To make painting easier, remove your cabinet doors and lay them on a flat surface, like a worktable or sawhorses. You can remove the doors by using a drill or screwdriver to take out the screws that hold the hinges in place. Make sure the area underneath them is protected with paper or cloth. Label your cabinet doors so you know where they go when you put them back. Remove the hinges before you paint your cabinets if you plan on upgrading them as well. If you are painting the shelves or exterior of the cabinet as well as the doors, you may want to cover your countertops with paper to protect them from paint drips.

steps.headline: Clean all surfaces to be painted with a degreaser.
steps.description: Kitchen cabinets can become grimy from built-up food grease. Even if your cabinets appear clean, use a dry rag and a degreaser such as dish soap or a trisodium phosphate (TSP) product to clean any surfaces you will be painting.

steps.headline: Fill any holes or dings with spackle.
steps.description: Inspect your cabinets carefully for any visible holes or cracks. If you find any, fill them with spackle and use a putty knife to smooth the spackle down. Check the instructions on the spackle to see how long it should dry.

steps.headline: Sand the cabinets by hand with 100-grit sandpaper.
steps.description: Roughing up the surface of the cabinets will give the new paint something to hold onto. Sand the doors and any other surfaces you plan to paint by hand, and clear away the dust with a vacuum. It’s a good idea to wear a dust mask or respirator while you work, to prevent sawdust from entering your lungs. If your cabinets are already painted and they’re in good condition, you don’t need to sand them.

steps.headline: Prime the cabinets with white primer paint.
steps.description: Use a mini-roller or paintbrush to apply a coat of primer to the doors and any other surfaces you plan to paint. If any brush strokes are visible after it dries, sand them out with 220-grit sandpaper.

steps.headline: Apply 1-2 coats of paint.
steps.description: Once the primer has dried completely, use a mini-roller or paintbrush to cover the surface with paint. Work slowly, go with the grain of the wood, and avoid piling paint at corners and edges. When painting the doors, let one side dry completely before flipping them and painting the opposite side. It can be helpful to have a smaller paintbrush on hand to even out piled-up paint or to reach small corners. Use a 2-in-1 paint and primer if you don’t want to wait for primer to dry. Use a satin or semi-gloss paint for your cabinets so they’re easier to clean once they dry.

steps.headline: Re-hang your cabinet doors once the paint has dried completely.
steps.description: Wait several hours to make sure the paint is dry, since even a small drop of wet paint can turn into an unsightly drip if you move the doors too soon. If necessary, have someone help you hold the doors in place while you screw the hinges back on.

steps.headline: Install crown molding to add dimension to your cabinets.
steps.description: This can be a great way to add interesting features to your cabinets, and make your kitchen appear more classic and sophisticated. This works best for cabinets that have some wood between the top of the doors and the ceiling. It’s better to install crown molding when you’re repainting your cabinets to ensure that the colors match. It’s important to measure the angles of your cabinets accurately, so that you can cut the molding to fit correctly. This can be done with a tool called an angle gauge, which is available at most hardware stores.

steps.headline: Apply a little bit of wood glue to the ends of each piece of crown molding before nailing it in place.
steps.description: Be aware that if you are looking for crown molding to match older wooden cabinets, buying molding made of the same wood will not necessarily ensure that it’s the same color.

steps.headline: Switch out your knobs or handles for a quick, easy upgrade.
steps.description: This is one of the most convenient ways to give your cabinets a more interesting appearance. Look for new knobs or handles in your local hardware store and use them to replace your old ones. Buy a set or mix and match. Your old knobs or handles should be easy to remove with a screwdriver or drill. The screws should be visible on either the face or the inside of the cabinet door. If your knobs are in good condition, you can remove and spray paint them to update how they look.

steps.headline: Use wallpaper to dress up dull cabinets or hide nicks and dings.
steps.description: Cutting pieces of wallpaper to fit the inner panel of your cabinet doors can be a quick way to update their look. It can also hide any nicks, dings or stains that have accumulated over the years. Use spray adhesive to stick the wallpaper on, and coat the whole door with a thin layer of decoupage after it dries. While you can use any kind of paper, wallpaper is ideal because it tends to be thicker and more moisture-resistant than regular paper, and can usually be cleaned. Use a contact paper with an adhesive back if you want a design you can easily remove.

steps.headline: Install under-cabinet light fixtures.
steps.description: Small lights under your upper cabinets can provide extra visibility and create an elegant, sophisticated look in your kitchen. You can choose from a variety of styles at your local home renovation store, including light bars and small, round “puck” lights. Some lighting products also feature dimmer switches, which can make the lights softer and more attractive. Use battery-powered LED strips under your cabinets if you don’t want to hardwire lights.

steps.headline: Upgrade your plate cabinet with a vertical rack.
steps.description: A rack can provide easy storage for plates and cutting boards. You can purchase one or put one together from a kit and use wood glue to secure it inside the cabinet. Make sure to leave at least 2 inches (5.1 cm) for the plates on either side of the rack.

steps.headline: Remove the doors from cramped cabinets.
steps.description: This will give you a couple extra inches of space for large or awkwardly shaped objects, and can also be a good way to showcase attractive dishes or interesting kitchen accessories. After you remove the doors, fill the screw holes with hardware putty and sand and repaint at least the face sides of the cabinet. This is not ideal for cabinets that store food, as the food will not be kept as fresh. Keep your dishes organized inside your cabinets if you remove the doors.

steps.headline: Install a sliding shelf for easy access.
steps.description: Some hard-to-reach cabinets don’t provide as much storage as they could simply because it’s inconvenient to access anything stored in the back. Installing a sliding shelf can take care of this problem, since it allows you to pull the entire shelf out of the cabinet for easy access. This is a great solution for pantry cabinets that might hold a variety of items you will want to access frequently.

steps.headline: Add a retractable rack for storing pots and pans.
steps.description: A simple pull-out rack can give you vertical storage space for hanging pots and pans, which can be awkward to store if they have long handles or don’t stack easily. If you have several pots and pans and use them frequently, it may be worth your while to install a retractable rack.

steps.headline: Use pop-up shelves in cabinets that have too much vertical space.
steps.description: If your cabinet shelves aren’t adjustable, they may be positioned so that you have more vertical space than you need for what you’re storing. You can make better use of this space by simply buying some pop-up shelves, which are usually made of lightweight metal like a shower caddy. This is a low-commitment storage solution, as you can remove them or move them around at any time.

steps.headline: Install hooks or shelves on the inside of cabinet doors for extra storage.
steps.description: Some cabinets, like the cabinet under your sink, may have plenty of space but very little shelving or organization. If there is enough space between the cabinet door and what’s stored inside, consider using hooks or lightweight shelves on the inside of the door. This can be helpful for storing spray bottles, pot lids, and large utensils. Install the hooks on the sides of your bottom cabinets or above your sink to hang dish towels.

text: Painting Your Cabinets Choose a light-colored paint to make your kitchen look bigger. To create a more open, spacious feel, look for paints in paler shades. Avoid glossy paints, as these will show any painting imperfections more visibly. Acrylic, or water-based, paints typically create fewer fumes and are easier to clean up than oil-based paints. Make your upper cabinets a lighter color and the bottom cabinets darker to make your space look more trendy. Make sure the 2 colors are complementary to one another. Take your cabinet doors off their hinges. To make painting easier, remove your cabinet doors and lay them on a flat surface, like a worktable or sawhorses.
